title: Bill Clinton Presidential Library: Records concerning Russian Internet Adoption and Independent Digital Forums (Live journal) (Sept 2000 – Jan 2001)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Bill Clinton Presidential Library: Records concerning Russian Internet Adoption and Independent Digital Forums (Live journal) (Sept 2000 – Jan 2001)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I request access to and copies of records within the National Security Council (NSC) and the White House Office of Records Management (WHORM) regarding the Clinton Administration’s awareness and analysis of Russian civil society’s adoption of US-based social media platforms, specifically LiveJournal ("Живой Журнал")

I. Scope of Request The time frame for this search is September 1, 2000, through January 20, 2001. I request that NARA search the following Record Groups:

NSC Intelligence Programs Directorate: Specifically files related to "Information Operations," "Cyber Policy," or "Russian Political Stability."
NSC Russian, Ukrainian, and Eurasian Affairs Directorate: Records concerning the transition from the Yeltsin to the Putin administration and the subsequent crackdown on traditional media (e.g., the NTV/Media-Most seizure).
NSC Records Management System (RMS): Search for cables and profile sheets originating from the CIA, NSA, or U.S. Embassy Moscow regarding digital dissent.

II. Specific Records Requested

Daily Intelligence Briefings: All Presidential Daily Briefs (PDBs), Senior Executive Intelligence Briefs (SEIBs), or Intelligence Summaries - of fragments thereof - that mention the growth of the Russian-language internet (Runet) or the use of "personal journaling" or "web diaries" or "online journal" software by Russian political figures, journalists, or intellectuals.

The "ZheZhe" Phenomenon: Any reports or cables discussing the relocation of Russian political discourse to servers located in the United States (specifically Danga Interactive or LiveJournal.)
Surveillance and Information Security: Any records discussing the Russian government’s (FSB) early attempts to monitor or interfere with US-hosted websites used by Russian nationals.
Staff Communications: Emails or memoranda from NSC staff (such as Jack Pritchard or Glyn Davies) regarding the "Digital Divide" in Russia or the emergence of "virtual parliaments" in Moscow.

III. Keywords for Search 

Please include the following search terms in your electronic and textual search: "LiveJournal", "Zhivoy Zhurnal", "Brad Fitzpatrick", "Danga Interactive", "online dissent", "Runet", "media-most", "virtual parliament", "web diary", "online journal", "internet diary" "weblog", "blog", "blogging", "Russian blogging", "Russian bloggers", "Живой Журнал" and "journaling software".

Format and Declassification: I request that these records be provided in electronic format (PDF). I am aware that many records in the NSC Intelligence Programs directorate may be classified. I request that these documents be subjected to a Mandatory Declassification Review (MDR) if they are found to be responsive but currently withheld under Exemption 1. If certain parts of this request or certain portions must be redacted please provide any reasonable segregable portion of a requested record after removing or redacting those portions claimed to be exempt, explain in writing the justification for redacting the record, indicate the extent of any redactions on the portion of the record which is made available or published and where technically feasible indicate on the redacted portion itself the specific exemption(s) claimed.

Thank you to the William J. Clinton Library, and the library's commitment to transparency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware
